text: Tom Watson is a Tory
author: TomBoadle

text:
The amount of replies to these two tweets that say Theresa May’s deal “isn’t leaving” the EU. 

They might not like the deal, but it is one in which we leave and it’s astonishing Brexiteers are so close to losing that chance.
author: TomBoadle

text: True, but they were fairly bullish that hauliers would be able to run smoothly through their ports and so to their ferries.
author: TomBoadle

text:
There is good news though. 

Brittany Ferries also told us that they are “as ready as we can ever be for all eventualities” - including a no-deal Brexit.
author: TomBoadle

text: Govt sources told @AdamParsons1 the Dept for Transport will now try to reduce the costs to the taxpayer by trying to offload their extra capacity to hauliers, but admitted they won’t be able to recoup the money spent.
author: TomBoadle

text:
The Govt has paid £90m for additional ferry services that will begin on 29 March, regardless of the politics.

Brittany Ferries told us: “deal or no-deal, extension or no extension, we’re absolutely committed to the new schedules”.
author: TomBoadle

text:
BMW Mini, Honda and Jaguar Land Rover are all going ahead with their planned shutdowns on the 29 March. 

A Brexit contingency plan now terribly timed should we leave without a deal two weeks later.
author: TomBoadle

text:
Many businesses wanted a deal, now they don’t even have a date. 

One of the country’s biggest chilled storage companies today told us the Brexit extension adds to the uncertainty and their customer’s costs. 

The boss said these past few weeks have been “absolutely horrendous”.
author: TomBoadle

text: For those interested, here's a full breakdown of which Government departments have taken out non-disclosure agreements over Brexit... and which can't or are refusing to tell us.
author: TomBoadle

text: Thanks Ben.
author: TomBoadle

text: After months of submitting and re-submitting Freedom of Information requests, @hmtreasury and @DefraGovUK have told me they too have used NDAs but can’t tell me how many, while @beisgovuk said it’s not in the public interest to reveal the number... despite other depts doing so!
author: TomBoadle

text: The UK Chamber of Shipping told us most of the NDAs their members have been forced to sign have now been lifted, but they told us the use of them “has limited the time available to exporters to understand future [customs] procedures”.
author: TomBoadle

text: The British Ports Association told us: “Signing NDAs can disrupt the necessary flow of information... We have found it difficult to share some information that may have helped smooth preparations with ports and customs authorities in Ireland and mainland Europe.”
author: TomBoadle

text: The Food and Drink Federation told us: “Where NDAs have been employed this clearly creates a two-tier relationship with industry, with some businesses being insiders and others kept out of the loop. Quite apart from the practical consequences, it is no way to build trust.”
author: TomBoadle

text:
Those forced to sign them by Govt claim they have stifled their ability to prepare.

Road Haulage Association told us: “It’s not fair and it is simply wrong to use them in this way. They are gagging trade associations like ours from telling our members about the effect of Brexit”
author: TomBoadle

text:
Exclusive: Sky News can reveal that the Government has hundreds of gagging orders as part of its preparations for a no-deal.

Home Office has signed over 100
Dept for Transport has signed 79
Dept of Health has signed 26
Brexit Dept has signed 7
author: TomBoadle

text: Macron: if Theresa May’s deal is rejected again, we will go for a no-deal.
author: TomBoadle

text:
Left: signatories to the petition calling for the government to "Revoke Article 50 and remain in the EU"

Right: the EU referendum result

Nothing has changed.
author: TomBoadle

text:
Overnight five mosques were attacked in Birmingham with sledgehammers. Being investigated by counter-terror police.

Story here: https://news.sky.com/story/birmingham-mosques-attacked-with-sledgehammers-11671537 …
author: TomBoadle

text: Retailer Next says a no-deal Brexit could save it up to £15m thanks to lower tariffs and that it would pass on "modest" savings to shoppers.
author: TomBoadle

text:
It's back up... this petition is getting big numbers
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/241584 …
author: TomBoadle

text: Deep state at work
author: TomBoadle

text: Again, you’re right that party politics is playing a big part in the process which the public will find contemptible but for the next few days she needs to do everything to get them on side. After that, she can have a go at them all she likes.
author: TomBoadle

text: She (and you) might be right, but her immediate problem is with Parliament, not the people. She could have explained the extension but been more conciliatory towards MPs.
author: TomBoadle

text: Theresa May’s address to the nation would make sense if she was calling an election or a second referendum, but why would you attack MPs - the very people you need to pass your deal - even if they are trying to thwart you. Tone deaf move.
author: TomBoadle

text: Chuka calls Corbyn “juvenile” for walking out of a meeting with the PM because he was there. 9 days to go.
author: TomBoadle

text: The country is coming together at last. 90% of the British public, eh...
author: TomBoadle

text: Theresa May, with no apparent self-awareness, says: "The House has voted on these issues and has rejected them."
author: TomBoadle

text: As the PM writes to the @eucopresident requesting an extension until 30 June, Reuters reveals an EU Commission document says an extension to 30 June would be legally and politically difficult - and that May can either have an extension until 23 May or at least to the end of 2019.
author: TomBoadle

text:
1,000 days since the referendum.
9 days until a no-deal Brexit.
The season finale is going to be...
author: TomBoadle

text: Their children might even be gay themselves.
author: TomBoadle

text:
International Development Secretary @PennyMordaunt confirms that 58 civil servants have been deployed to assist with no-deal Brexit preparations and that they're considering deploying another 170 people.

These are civil servants who are paid to "end extreme poverty".
author: TomBoadle

text:
Not interested in getting involved in twitter fights, but the rest of this thread is interesting. 

Why are spree killings carried out predominantly by men? Why are men more prone to commits acts of terror? Understanding that may help prevent these sorts of atrocities.
author: TomBoadle

text: Miller won the right for MPs to approve Article 50, which provided the opportunity for MPs to win the right to a Meaningful Vote.
author: TomBoadle

text: Lewis was bang on the money last week: “You can always rely on John Bercow to be controversial and push the auspices of his office. Don’t count it out.”
author: TomBoadle

text: Chances of a no-deal Brexit just went up, but so too have the chances of a longer extension and a softer Brexit.
author: TomBoadle

text:
Tory ERG member Sir Bill Cash tells Bercow that what he said “makes an enormous amount of sense”. 

Jacob Rees-Mogg follows with further praise.

Brexit never fails to surprise.
author: TomBoadle

text: Bercow: “the Govt cannot resubmit to the House the same proposition, or substantially the same proposition” as was voted upon last week
author: TomBoadle

text:
Can the government bring back May’s deal for third Meaningful Vote?

Bercow now setting out the rules of Parliament that state: “a question which has been decided during a session may not be brought forward again during the same session.”
author: TomBoadle

text: He’s behind you! #RobotWars #DeepOceanLive
author: TomBoadle

text: Big fan of this new series of Robot Wars #DeepOceanLive
author: TomBoadle

text:
This is cool. Sky’s @annabotting presenting live from the ocean deep in a world first to draw attention to the plight of the world's oceans. #DeepOceanLive #UnderTheSea

Watch live here: https://youtu.be/lrX6ktLg8WQ 

Follow here: https://news.sky.com/story/deep-ocean-live-sky-to-broadcast-first-tv-news-bulletins-under-the-sea-11669146 …?
author: TomBoadle

text: Think rugby’s the winner there.
author: TomBoadle

text: Big fan of this thread.
author: TomBoadle

text:
In 30 years of reporting on Westminster @adamboultonSKY has never seen a PM and a Parliament in a bigger crisis. Politics is in meltdown.

I made this short film with him to explain just what the hell is going on and just how unprecedented it is.

Watch: https://youtu.be/_zDF09KK8fM
author: TomBoadle
